results.title: The Living tundra
results.creator_credit: Richard Brock, British Petroleum and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “The Web of life”.
A study of the ecology of the Alaskan tundra, showing it in winter when it is barren and locked in snow and ice, and in spring when flocks of wild fowl fly in and the tundra becomes covered in flowers.

results.title: The Living soil
results.creator_credit: Nicholas Alexander, CSIRO and Roger Seccombe
results.brief_description: Without spoken commentary, this film depicts both the life of the soil and the life within it. The film also demonstrates through photography, the chemical cycle of soil. For many people soil is just dirt. Yet through the fresh eye of the camera, soil is seen as the home of a vital community.

results.title: The Living savanna
results.creator_credit: Richard Brock, British Petroleum and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Web of life”.
Includes scenes of wildlife in East Africa and shows how the various animals fit into the ecosystem. Also shows the effects of any alteration to the balance of nature. Suitable for secondary level.

results.title: The Living river
results.creator_credit: Richard Brock, British Petroleum and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “The Web of life”.
Thoughtless actions by humans can easily upset the delicately adjusted balance of life in a river. Shows how the seasons, weather, flora and fauna of the River Test are all integrated and woven into a “web of life”. Includes underwater shots of birds feeding from the river bed and thousands of eels on migration.

results.title: The Living reef (Captioned)
results.brief_description: A program that gives a general description of the Great Barrier Reef, how it developed and the diversity of life found above and below water. It depicts the interdependence of the many different species of animal life inhabiting the Reef.
results.description: A program that gives a general description of the Great Barrier Reef, how it developed and the diversity of life found above and below water. It depicts the interdependence of the many different species of animal life inhabiting the Reef.

results.title: The Living reef
results.creator_credit: Ken J. Widdowson and Film Victoria
results.brief_description: The longest and largest reef in the world lies off the North-East Coast of Australia. The Great Barrier Reef extends from New Guinea to central Queensland.

results.title: The Living rain forest
results.creator_credit: Richard Brock, British Petroleum and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Web of life”.
Stresses the balance of nature within this ecosystem. Each level of the rain forest ecosystem is carefully examined to show the food chains present. Suitable for secondary level.

results.title: The Living planet. - Part 1: the building of the earth
results.brief_description: Part One of a two part series. From the sub zero temperatures of the polar ice-caps to the baking heat of the deserts, from the ash-strewn sides of a volcano to the dense vegetation of a tropical forest, the environments on Earth are no less remarkable than the variety of life itself and almost nowhere on our planet is devoid of life. Narrated by David Attenborough.
results.title_for_label: The Living planet. - Part 1: the building of the earth

results.title: The Living mountains
results.creator_credit: Richard Brock, British Petroleum and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “The Web of life”.
Looks at some of the strange plants seen on a journey from the shores of the Caribbean in Venezuela to the moorlands and peaks of the Andes Mountains, then across the world to Mount Kenya, with its weird giant plants and tiny sunbirds. Shows how plants and animals survive in extreme conditions and also indicates that today the seemingly invulnerable mountains are less secure from human intrusion.

results.title: The Living mammal
results.brief_description: Common characteristics held by all mammals. Various ways in which mammals have adapted themselves to life in the water, air, treetops and on the ground. The highly developed senses of sight, smell, touch and hearing combined in the hunt for food. The adaptations of teeth for herbivorous, carnivorous and ominivorous modes of life. Methods of self-protection and ways in which different mammals care for and rear their young.
